questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with shortness of breath and chest pain 35 minutes after he was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He was the helmeted driver of a scooter hit by a truck. On arrival, he is alert and oriented with a Glasgow Coma Scale rating of 14. His temperature is 37.3째C (99.1째F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 33/min and blood pressure is 132/88 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. Examination shows multiple abrasions over his anterior abdomen and extremities. There is a 2.5-cm (1-in) laceration on the left side of the chest. There are decreased breath sounds over the left base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and there is tenderness to palpation over the left upper quadrant. Bowel sounds are normal. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.6 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9110/mm3, and platelet count is 190,000/mm3. A chest x-ray is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Diaphragmatic rupture is most commonly caused by penetrating injuries, followed by blunt trauma, both of which can be caused by a high-speed motor vehicle collision. Clinical features include chest/abdominal wall bruises, decreased breath sounds due to herniation of abdominal contents into the chest, and respiratory distress. Chest auscultation may reveal bowel sounds. Chest x-ray may show disturbed contour of the hemidiaphragm, displaced abdominal organs, and mediastinal shift, as well as an hourglass sign if abdominal contents are constricted at the defect. A CT scan of the chest and abdomen is necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

Diaphragmatic ruptures more commonly occur on the left side because the right diaphragm is protected by the liver. Patients may initially be asymptomatic, so this condition is often not diagnosed immediately.

B) INCORRECT:

Esophageal perforation may occur in a variety of clinical scenarios, including Boerhaave syndrome, blunt and penetrating chest trauma, and iatrogenic esophageal perforation (e.g., following endoscopy). Patients with esophageal perforation present with chest pain, tachycardia, and tachypnea. However, this condition is often associated with additional findings such as fever and crepitus over the chest due to mediastinal emphysema. Unlike in this patient, a chest x-ray typically shows a widened mediastinum. Herniation of the stomach into the thorax is not typically associated with esophageal perforation.

C) INCORRECT:

Flail chest can cause respiratory distress due to detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall, which results from three or more adjacent ribs fractured in two or more places. While flail chest can occur following high-velocity trauma, the absence of rib fractures on this patient's chest x-ray rules this condition out.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (AP view; supine) of patient with a history of trauma

Multiple right rib fractures (red lines) are present, some of which show marked displacement. There is extensive subcutaneous emphysema (examples indicated by arrowheads). The right lung is diffusely opaque (green overlay), likely reflective of pulmonary contusion in view of the trauma history.

White overlay: ribs

D) INCORRECT:

A pneumothorax can occur spontaneously or following trauma such as a high-speed motor vehicle collision. Patients typically present with tachypnea, dyspnea, chest pain, and unilaterally reduced breath sounds. However, a chest x-ray usually shows a pleural line, a sudden change in radiolucency, and an abrupt stop in pulmonary vascular markings. This patient's x-ray findings are not consistent with a pneumothorax.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

A thin white line represents the visceral pleura of the left lung (dotted line). No lung markings are seen peripheral to the visceral pleura (green overlay).

The appearance is consistent with a left pneumothorax. There is no evidence of contralateral mediastinal shift, diaphragmatic depression, or ipsilateral intercostal space widening to suggest tension pneumothorax.

E) INCORRECT:

The phrenic nerve innervates the diaphragm via the nerve roots C3, C4, and C5. Phrenic nerve palsy is often iatrogenic (e.g., following supraclavicular block) and may occasionally occur following trauma. This condition leads to ipsilateral elevation of the diaphragm, which affects pulmonary and cardiac function. Patients can present with dyspnea. However, x-ray usually shows elevation of the diaphragm on the affected side and not herniation of abdominal contents into the thorax.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (lateral view)

There is elevation of the left hemidiaphragm (dashed line) with adjacent atelectasis (yellow overlay) of lung parenchyma and underlying dilated bowel (B).

Blue overlay: hardware left humerus; solid line: right hemidiaphragm

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a penetrating stab wound to the left lower chest during an altercation. He reports shortness of breath and left-sided chest pain. Vital signs are BP, 118/76; P, 98; oxygen saturation, 94% on room air. Physical examination shows diminished breath sounds over the left lower chest with dullness to percussion. Chest x-ray is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Focused assessment with sonography for trauma
Computed tomography of the chest and abdomen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic laparoscopy is indicated in hemodynamically stable patients when imaging studies are negative but clinical suspicion for diaphragmatic hernia remains high. This approach allows direct visualization and potential repair of small diaphragmatic defects but should not be the initial diagnostic modality in trauma patients.

B) INCORRECT:

FAST examination can identify diaphragmatic hernias through decreased diaphragmatic movement and bowel loops in the thorax. However, this modality provides limited anatomical detail and may miss smaller defects or fail to adequately assess the extent of injury in penetrating thoracoabdominal trauma.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- CT of the chest and abdomen is the most appropriate next step in hemodynamically stable patients with suspected diaphragmatic injury following trauma. CT can identify discontinuity of the diaphragm, erniated abdominal contents, and the collar sign of bowel constriction. This patient's hemodynamic stability allows for comprehensive imaging assessment before surgical decision-making.

D) INCORRECT:

Chest tube placement poses significant risk when diaphragmatic hernia is suspected, as the injury can mimic pneumothorax radiographically. Inadvertent tube placement through herniated bowel can cause perforation, evidenced by drainage of air mixed with bile or fecal material, representing a serious iatrogenic complication.

E) INCORRECT:

Emergency laparotomy is appropriate for hemodynamically unstable patients or those with clear evidence of multiple organ injury. This hemodynamically stable patient with isolated suspected diaphragmatic injury requires further diagnostic workup to characterize the injury pattern and guide surgical approach rather than immediate operative intervention.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision is brought to the emergency department complaining of left-sided chest pain and shortness of breath. His blood pressure is 105/75 mm Hg and respirations are 28/min. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds over the left lower lung field. An initial chest radiograph shows an opacified left hemithorax with an elevated hemidiaphragm. What additional physical finding is most likely to support the suspected diagnosis?

choices.text: Tracheal deviation toward the affected side
Hyperresonance to percussion over the left chest

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tracheal deviation toward the affected (left) side indicates a loss of volume in the left hemithorax, as seen in conditions like atelectasis or lobar collapse. The herniation of abdominal organs into the chest creates a mass effect, which would push the trachea and other mediastinal structures away from the affected side (to the right), not toward it.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperresonance to percussion suggests an accumulation of air in the pleural space, a key finding in pneumothorax. In diaphragmatic rupture, the presence of solid or fluid-filled abdominal viscera in the chest cavity, along with potential atelectasis of the underlying lung, would cause dullness to percussion, not hyperresonance. The opacified hemithorax on the radiograph also argues against a simple pneumothorax.

C) INCORRECT:

Paradoxical chest wall movement is the hallmark physical finding of a flail chest. This condition results from multiple fractures in three or more contiguous ribs, creating an unstable segment that moves inward on inspiration and outward on expiration. While this is a serious chest injury, it is distinct from diaphragmatic rupture, and the stem provides no information about multiple rib fractures.

D) CORRECT:

Blunt thoracoabdominal trauma can cause a diaphragmatic rupture, which is more common on the left side due to the protective effect of the liver on the right. The resulting defect allows abdominal viscera (e.g., stomach, spleen, colon) to herniate into the thoracic cavity. This displacement of organs out of the abdomen reduces intra-abdominal volume, which can manifest as a sunken or scaphoid abdomen. This finding, in conjunction with the patient's respiratory distress, decreased breath sounds on the left side, and chest radiograph findings, strongly supports the diagnosis. Auscultation of bowel sounds in the chest is another classic, though less common, finding.

E) INCORRECT:

In the context of trauma, jugular venous distention (JVD) is a critical sign of impaired venous return to the heart, most commonly caused by tension pneumothorax or cardiac tamponade. While a very large diaphragmatic hernia could cause some mediastinal shift and increase intrathoracic pressure, JVD is not a specific or characteristic finding for this injury.
questions.hint: This patient's chest radiograph findings suggest that abdominal contents have herniated into the thoracic cavity.
